Award.AwardTitle: Computational Thinking as an Approach to Refining the Critical Thinking and Analytical Reasoning Skills of Undergraduates at an HBCU

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project entitled - Computational Thinking as an Approach to Refining the Critical Thinking and Analytical Reasoning Skills of Undergraduates at an HBCU - has the goal to expand on a new course in Computational Thinking to ensure that students who complete this course have enhanced critical thinking and analytical reasoning skills. The objectives of this project are: to identify and develop exact measures of Computational Thinking competencies; to develop a curriculum that successfully integrates critical thinking and analytical reasoning skills with Computational Thinking skills; and to determine whether Computational Thinking competencies enhance critical thinking and analytical reasoning skills for students at Jackson State University.

This project will contribute to the newly evolving area of Computational Thinking. Advocates of computational thinking believe that it will transform not only Computer Science education, but K-16 education in general. Ninety-Two percent of the students enrolled at Jackson State University are African-American. As part of the institution's core curriculum all students must take a computing course. Therefore, this project has the potential to impart Computational Thinking, critical thinking and analytical reasoning skills to a large number of underrepresented students. This project will ensure that HBCUs and other minority serving institutions are a part of the evolving Computational Thinking community. Course modules and a theoretical framework resulting from this project will be disseminated through traditional means such as publications and presentations as well as various computing related pathways.

Project Overview: The overall objective of the "Computational Thinking as an Approach to Refining the Critical Thinking and Analytical Reasoning Skills of Undergraduates at an HBCU" project was to determine whether Computational Thinking could be used to improved the analytical reasoning and critical thinking skills of undergraduate students. The major goals of this project were to: 1) develop curriculum that successfully integrates critical thinking and analytical reasoning skills with Computational Thinking skills; 2) identify and develop exact measures of Computational Thinking competencies; and 3)determine whether Computational Thinking competencies enhance critical thinking and analytical reasoning skills for students at JSU.   

Project Activities: The project involved the following major activities: 1) curriculum development; 2) professional development opportunities for faculty, undergraduate and graduate students; and 3) dissemination.

Activity 1: Curriculum Development This project supported the revision of an existing Computational Thinking course. The Computational Thinking course introduced students to the principles of computational thinking, focusing on the fundamental concepts of computing as they apply to various disciplines. Topics included data analysis and visualization, virtual organizations, emergency management and mobile computing. In the latest revision of the course, students were expected to: 

Apply analytical reasoning and critical thinking skills to construct basic physical and virtual models using various technologies 

Analyze physical and virtual models to determine appropriateness of solution 

Throughout the course of the semester, students were exposed to Computing and Computational Thinking through five different projects in the areas of 1) Computing, Data Analysis and Modeling; 2) Emergency Management; 3) Music and Math; 4) Entrepreneurship; and 5) The Virtual Workforce.  Each project emphasized computational competencies of problem decomposition, pattern recognition, pattern generalization, algorithm design, data visualization, abstraction analysis, communication and collaboration. Students divided into multidisciplinary teams to create innovative solutions to various social problems. Students not only used technology to solve problems but were also given opportunities to evaluate material and strengthen their abilities in deduction, comprehension, creative thinking and ethical reasoning. Students were asked to journal their experiences and write reflective essays of their work and created electronic portfolios that showcased their work.   Computational Thinking was also successfully integrated into ITEM 401 Computer Applications in Emergency Management. Each student was required to design a mobile application containing important information that people can use before, during and after an emergency or disaster. The emergency management app design project encouraged students to think creatively as well as apply critical and computational thinking and problem solving skills to real world problems.

Undergraduate students participated in a summer workshop that focused on developing critical thinking skills through Computational Thinking. During the workshop, students participated in a set of activities that were designed to strengthen their programming skills.
